user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ExecuteBasicHandler:
```c
void UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler)
{
    /* Check if the test case registered a hook, and use the default if not */
    if (UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER) == NULL && DefaultHandler != NULL)
    {
        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_ExecuteBasicHandler:
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
...
void UT_SetHandlerFunction(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_HandlerFunc_t HandlerFunc, void *UserObj)
{
    UT_HookFuncPtr_t Value;

    Value.SimpleHandler = HandlerFunc;

    UT_DoSetHookFunction(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER, Value, UserObj, false);
}
...
int32 UT_DefaultStubImpl(const char *FunctionName, UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 DefaultRc, ...)
{
    int32   Retcode;
    va_list va;

    va_start(va, DefaultRc);
    Retcode = UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs(FunctionName, FuncKey, DefaultRc, va);
    va_end(va);

    return Retcode;
}
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef void (*UT_HandlerFunc_t)(void *UserObj, UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const UT_StubContext_t *Context)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No explicit compiler language extensions (such as __attribute__, __asm__, __extension__, __declspec, GCC statement expressions, nested functions, typeof, or other vendor-specific keywords) are present in the provided code fragments. The constructs present are standard C: function definitions, pointer usage, modulo and indexing operations, while(1) loop, function pointers (UT_HandlerFunc_t), variadic function usage (va_list, ...), and typedefs for integer types (uint32, int32) which are typical and not language extensions by themselves. The only item that might warrant external verification is the underlying definitions of the typedef names (cpuaddr, uint32, int32, UT_StubTableEntry_t, etc.); those could be aliases for standard types or provided by headers — if any of those are themselves implemented using a compiler-specific extension, that would be the actual violation, but such uses are not visible in the supplied code. Therefore, based on the shown code, there are no fragments that explicitly use documented compiler language extensions.
